awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Adaptive, Multi-Layered Fenestration Elements for Optimum Building Energy Performance and Occupant Comfort
awd_abstract_narration:
As buildings work towards reducing energy demands, while maintaining a both thermally and visually comfortable environment for occupants, fenestrations (i.e. windows) are a key influential component in this effort. Fenestrations allow for natural daylight and outdoor views, but also represent the least thermally efficient portion of the building envelope, as well as a source of unwanted discomfort glare and direct sunlight. A multi-layered, dynamically-operated fenestration system that can be installed in new buildings or retrofitted for an existing building will address building energy use and occupant comfort needs under a diverse range of climate conditions. The project will explore the theoretical and practical challenges for the building industry to develop a model for the performance of dynamic fenestration designs to enhance building energy sustainability and human health.  To encourage exchanging of ideas internationally, the research team will collaborate with European colleagues through the European Commission Horizon 2020 PLUG-N-HARVEST project. In addition, instructional and interdisciplinary research opportunities will be provided for graduate and undergraduate students of civil, mechanical, and materials engineering to serve a vital need, particularly from existing buildings.  

This research will lay the theoretical and practical foundations for the intelligent control and operations of smart and energy efficient fenestrations by developing an adaptive, multi-layered solution. This includes: (a) a dual-band, continuous-state electrochromic glazing applied to the window exterior in a matrix pattern to enable localized control, (b) a motorized and dynamically-operated shading device, and (c) a novel, multi-physics model-based adaptive control framework, with the goal of balancing a range of building energy consumption and occupant thermal and visual comfort priorities in real time. The exterior 2-dimensional electrochromic glazing array combined with a second dynamic layer on the fenestration interior provides the ability to address localized occupant visual comfort challenges, and allows for a broader range of capabilities to control solar heat gains, while addressing differences in occupant comfort criteria. The model framework solution will be tested and evaluated using simulations, and a full-scale testbed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on investigating the development and testing of smart, dynamic, multi-layered fenestration systems to improve the visual and thermal performance of window systems. This was investigated through a combination of dynamic fenestration control development, energy and daylight co-simulation to evaluate performance, multiphysics modeling, and laboratory development and testing of a novel electrochromic glazing component. Full scale testing data was also used to validate components of simulation results.

 

For the electrochromic (EC) glazing behavior, multiphysics modeling was based on a pseudo-two-dimensional model with an integrated response surface which enabled the simulation of the optical responses of the EC glazing. This also included a Fresnel model to simulate optical properties for different solar angles. Results of the modeling suggest good potential performance as an EC glazing. Fabrication of the dual-band EC glazing based on niobium-doped titanium oxide thin film resulted in an optical transmittance, measured in situ, of 350 to 2500 nm. Results from fabrication were then used to develop an input file for simulation of the EC glazing, in addition to the simulation of the dynamic shading and lighting components and controls. Simulation completed using RADIANCE, EnergyPlus, Rhino, Grasshopper, Honeybee and Ladybug, using a 12-mode control strategy provided a comparative analysis of demand response potential, energy consumption impacts, and visual comfort impacts for a range of orientations, zone types, and sensor placement considerations. Results suggest strong potential for HVAC (in particular, for cooling) and lighting energy savings while maintaining visual comfort criteria.  Results also suggest that in targeting both energy savings and demand reduction (through demand response participation), there is a trade off between strategies and configurations that prioritize energy savings and those that prioritize demand reduction potential that should be considered.

Findings of this project have been communicated to the public in presentations at conferences and institutions. We have published three journal papers, with several more in review as of November 2023. We also presented several conferences papers at ASHRAE conferences and ASCE Construction Research Congress conferences. In addition, we have communicated knowledge gained from this project at students’ research conferences, poster competitions, and related meetings.
